html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td h3 span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td span
content: About one in seven Australian adults suffer from some form of high blood pressure, or hypertension (as it's known medically). If you're one of them, monitoring your condition regularly at home with a blood pressure monitor (and in co-operation with your GP) can be useful.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Buy from a pharmacy or medical equipment supplier, where you can get proper advice and a demonstration of how to use the monitor.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Arm monitors are generally more accurate than wrist models; in our test, only one wrist model could match them.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If you buy an arm monitor, measure your arm size to get the right-size cuff.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Make sure the monitor's keys and display are easy to read.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Models that inflate the cuff automatically tend to work better than those requiring you to do it manually (by pumping a bulb), though there are exceptions.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: The cuff has to be inflated to a level above the systolic blood pressure. However, the automatic setting on the monitor may be a lot higher, and you may find it uncomfortable. Models with adjustable inflation level allow you to program the pressure to one that's comfortable for you. Models with fuzzy logic detect the ideal inflation level automatically.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If a monitor has a memory to store a number of your recent blood pressure measurements, it can be helpful as a back-up. However, it's a good idea to record all measurements separately, so that you and your GP get a sufficient history.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Manufacturers give different advice regarding the use of rechargeable batteries; check in the shop before you buy.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: While you should use a blood pressure monitor in co-operation with your GP, it's still very helpful if the monitor comes with good general background information on blood pressure issues, for your reference.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td h3 span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td span
content: Blood pressure is created by the heart pumping blood through the arteries. It's measured as two numbers, in millimetres of mercury (mmHg) based on the standard method using a mercury sphygmomanometer (the machine your doctor uses in their surgery) and a stethoscope; giving a result such as '120 over 80' (120/80 mmHg).

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: The higher figure is the systolic pressure, caused by the contracting (beating) heart. The lower figure is called diastolic, and is the pressure between beats, when the heart relaxes.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td p span
content: Hypertension can increase the risk of heart attack, stroke, heart failure and kidney disease, but doesn't necessarily do so. When weighing up your risk, your GP will also consider factors such as your age, sex, family history and weight, and whether you smoke.

html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td h3 span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td span
content: Your lifestyle can have an impact on your blood pressure. To prevent hypertension or to manage it once you've been diagnosed:

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Have regular check-ups, especially when you know you have high blood pressure.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Limit the amount of alcohol you drink.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Exercise regularly (but note that there are certain sports to avoid when you have high blood pressure, such as lifting heavy weights). Consider stress-reducing techniques such as yoga and meditation.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Avoid salty and fatty foods, and reduce your consumption of red meat.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Eat plenty of cereals, fish, fruit and vegetables.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: Achieve and maintain a healthy body weight.

tag: html body text table tbody tr td table tbody tr td table tbody tr td ul li span
content: If lifestyle changes don't lower your blood pressure enough, your doctor may prescribe medication. Make sure you take it, and don't adjust the dosage yourself based on your own blood pressure measurements. This is known as 'self-diagnosis', and fiddling with your medication yourself can have serious consequences.
